author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@thogard**
> For block-level warming, how would that even be feasible from an adversarial standpoint? This might have already been covered but my hunch is that the only way it’d workis if you gave all of the gas refunds  at the very end of the block - otherwise I could write two txs that lead to an impossibility result by having
- tx1 (if a!=warm, call b)
- tx2 (if b!=warm, call a)
(I’m oversimplifying the attack but you get the idea)

But storing all of the balance refunds and then doing them all the at the end of the block seems suboptimal from an engineering perspective…. A whole bunch of extra state writes.
For BALs there are no refunds; or do you mean the other proposal?

author: bridge-bot
content: <shemnon> I think this was in reference to https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7557, which is distinct but related to BAL.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<shemnon> > But storing all of the balance refunds and then doing them all the at the end of the block seems suboptimal from an engineering perspective…. A whole bunch of extra state writes.

You don't calculate the MPT nor store to disk until after the post TX duties are done.  So no extra state writes as it's all in memory.  Around constantinople we stopped caring about sub-block MPT roots. There is no visibility in the code and the visibility in receipts was taken out as a performance improvement.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<brianbland> re: **@shemnon**
> > But storing all of the balance refunds and then doing them all the at the end of the block seems suboptimal from an engineering perspective…. A whole bunch of extra state writes.

You don't calculate the MPT nor store to disk until after the post TX duties are done.  So no extra state writes as it's all in memory.  Around constantinople we stopped caring about sub-block MPT roots. There is no visibility in the code and the visibility in receipts was taken out as a performance improvement.
Even if the extra state writes aren't actually committed to disk until the end of the block, this still prevents optimistic calculation of the MPT intermediate hashes, as most account balances will once again change at the very end.
